habitat_description:
Cynomys ludovicianus inhabits short- and mixed-grass prairies (Koford, 1958; Fitzgerald et al., 1994; Findley et al., 1975; Johnson and Collinge, 2003; Johnson-Nistler et al., 2004; Avila-Flores, 2012). It prefers maximum vegetation heights ranging from 13 to 64 m (Clippinger, 1989), although Roe and Roe (2003) assert that heights <30 cm are optimal. Common flora on praire dog towns include buffalograss, western wheatgrass, and blue grama (Koford, 1958; Fagerstone et al., 1981; Garrett et al., 1982; Agnew et al., 1986; Johnson-Nistler et al., 2004). Scattered shrubs or succulents may be present, and the black-tailed prairie dog will feed on them (Koford, 1958), with prickly pear providing a crucial winter water supply in some sites (Clippinger, 1989).

The species feeds on sand dropseed, sun sedge, blue grama, western wheatgrass, ring muhly, green needlegrass, fescue, Russian thistle, pricklypear, and saltbush (Koford, 1958; Uresk, 1984).

Prairie dog colonies are typically in low-lying areas or swales (Roach et al., 2001). Sandy or rocky soils are inhospitable to C. ludovicianus, as they hinder burrowing; silty clay loams and fine sandy loams are preferred (Clippinger, 1989; Roe and Roe, 2003).

The species is found from elevations below 1000 m in Texas (Pruett et al., 2009) and Arizona (Arizona Department of Fish and Game, 2004) to 1850 m in CO (Armstrong, 1972).
